newsitem.title: USA: Bonneville drops power price, raises transmission.
newsitem.headline: Bonneville drops power price, raises transmission.

text.p: The Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) said Tuesday it rejigged its next-day offer prices, lowering prices for raw energy while increasing transmission prices, especially for non-Northwest sales.
Raw energy refers to electricity prices excluding any transmission costs.

Firm on-peak power for Wednesday was offered by the federal power marketing agency at $17.62 per megawatt hour (MWh), but transmission charges brought that to $19.54 for Northwest deliveries and $22.00 for California-Oregon (COB) and Nevada-Oregon border (NOB) deals.
For Tuesday, BPA had offered the same power at $21.00 per MWh, plus $1.00 for transmission within the Northwest or $2.27 for COB or NOB sales.
Wednesday off-peak firm power was offered at $13.54 per MWh in the Northwest and at $16.00 at COB or NOB.
BPA also continued to limit Wednesday firm sales to 200 megawatts (MW) and non-firm to 500 MW.
Non-firm peak power on Wednesday was offered at $15.94 per MWh, or $18.48 in the Northwest and $21.00 at COB or NOB.
